etymology.description: 豆(豆) (dòu, "bean"), 瓣(瓣) (bàn, "petal"; "segment"), 酱(醬) (jiàng, "paste")
etymology.interpretation: 豆瓣醬 (dòubànjiàng, "doubanjiang") is a type of paste made from fermented broad beans, soybeans, and usually chili. The term 豆(豆) (dòu, "bean") indicates the primary ingredient, while 瓣(瓣) (bàn, "petal"; "segment") suggests the segmented appearance of the ingredients, and 酱(醬) (jiàng, "paste") denotes its form as a thick sauce. It is a staple in Sichuan cuisine, used for its rich umami flavor and spiciness.

examples.chinese: 我用豆瓣酱(豆瓣醬)，做鱼香茄子(魚香茄子)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yòng dòubànjiàng, zuò yúxiāng qiézi.
examples.english: I use doubanjiang to cook fish-flavored eggplant.

examples.chinese: 豆瓣酱(豆瓣醬)提升菜肴(菜肴)，带来独特味道(獨特味道)。
examples.pinyin: Dòubànjiàng tíshēng càiyáo, dàilái dútè wèidào.
examples.english: Doubanjiang enhances dishes and brings a unique flavor.

examples.chinese: 她学做菜时(學做菜時)，总用豆瓣酱(豆瓣醬)调味(調味)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xué zuòcài shí, zǒng yòng dòubànjiàng tiáowèi.
examples.english: When she learns to cook, she always uses doubanjiang for seasoning.
